'''Interest rate parity''' is a no-[[arbitrage]] condition representing an [[economic equilibrium|equilibrium]] state under which investors will be indifferent to [[interest rate]]s available on [[demand deposit|bank deposits]] in two countries.<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008">{{Cite book | title = International Macroeconomics | author = Feenstra, Robert C. | author2 = Taylor, Alan M. | year = 2008 | publisher = Worth Publishers | location = New York, NY | isbn = 978-1-4292-0691-4}}</ref> The fact that this condition does not always hold allows for potential opportunities to earn riskless profits from [[covered interest arbitrage]]. Two assumptions central to interest rate parity are [[capital mobility]] and [[substitute good|perfect substitutability]] of domestic and foreign [[assets]]. Given [[foreign exchange market]] equilibrium, the interest rate parity condition implies that the expected [[rate of return|return]] on domestic assets will equal the [[exchange rate]]-adjusted expected return on foreign currency assets. Investors cannot then earn arbitrage profits by borrowing in a country with a lower interest rate, exchanging for foreign currency, and investing in a foreign country with a higher interest rate, due to gains or losses from exchanging back to their domestic currency at [[maturity (finance)|maturity]].<ref name="Mishkin 2006">{{Cite book | title = Economics of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets, 8th edition | author = Mishkin, Frederic S. | year = 2006 | publisher = Addison-Wesley | location = Boston, MA | isbn = 978-0-321-28726-7}}</ref> Interest rate parity takes on two distinctive forms: ''uncovered interest rate parity'' refers to the parity condition in which exposure to [[foreign exchange risk]] (unanticipated changes in exchange rates) is uninhibited, whereas ''covered interest rate parity'' refers to the condition in which a [[forward contract]] has been used to ''cover'' (eliminate exposure to) exchange rate risk. Each form of the parity condition demonstrates a unique relationship with implications for the forecasting of future exchange rates: the [[forward exchange rate]] and the future [[spot exchange rate]].<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" />
Economists have found empirical evidence that covered interest rate parity generally holds, though not with precision due to the effects of various risks, costs, taxation, and ultimate differences in liquidity. When both covered and uncovered interest rate parity hold, they expose a relationship suggesting that the forward rate is an unbiased predictor of the future spot rate. This relationship can be employed to test whether uncovered interest rate parity holds, for which economists have found mixed results. When uncovered interest rate parity and [[purchasing power parity]] hold together, they illuminate a relationship named ''real interest rate parity'', which suggests that expected [[real interest rate]]s represent expected adjustments in the [[Exchange rate#Purchasing power of currency|real exchange rate]]. This relationship generally holds strongly over longer terms and among [[emerging markets|emerging market]] countries.
==Assumptions== Interest rate parity rests on certain assumptions, the first being that capital is mobile - investors can readily exchange domestic assets for foreign assets. The second assumption is that assets have perfect substitutability, following from their similarities in [[financial risk|riskiness]] and [[market liquidity|liquidity]]. Given capital mobility and perfect substitutability, investors would be expected to hold those assets offering greater returns, be they domestic or foreign assets. However, both domestic and foreign assets are held by investors. Therefore, it must be true that no difference can exist between the returns on domestic assets and the returns on foreign assets.<ref name="Mishkin 2006" /> That is not to say that domestic investors and foreign investors will earn equivalent returns, but that a single investor on any given side would expect to earn equivalent returns from either investment decision.<ref name="Madura 2007">{{Cite book| title = International Financial Management: Abridged 8th Edition | author = Madura, Jeff | year = 2007 | publisher = Thomson South-Western | location = Mason, OH | isbn = 0-324-36563-2}}</ref>
==Uncovered interest rate parity== [[File:Uncovered-interest-rate-parity.svg|thumb|right|375px|A visual representation of uncovered interest rate parity holding in the foreign exchange market, such that the returns from investing domestically are equal to the returns from investing abroad.]] When the no-arbitrage condition is satisfied ''without'' the use of a forward contract to hedge against exposure to exchange rate risk, interest rate parity is said to be ''uncovered''. Risk-neutral investors will be indifferent among the available interest rates in two countries because the exchange rate between those countries is expected to adjust such that the dollar return on dollar deposits is equal to the dollar return on foreign deposits, thereby eliminating the potential for [[uncovered interest arbitrage]] profits. Uncovered interest rate parity helps explain the [[spot exchange rate|determination of the spot exchange rate]]. The following equation represents uncovered interest rate parity.<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" />
:<math>(1 + i_\$) = \frac {E_t(S_{t + k})} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>
where :<math>E_t(S_{t + k})</math> is the expected future spot exchange rate at time ''t + k'' :''k'' is the number of periods into the future from time ''t'' :''S<sub>t</sub>'' is the current spot exchange rate at time ''t'' :''i<sub>$</sub>'' is the interest rate in the US :''i<sub>c</sub>'' is the interest rate in a foreign country or currency area (for this example, following a US perspective, it is the interest rate available in the [[Eurozone]])
The dollar return on dollar deposits, <math>1 + i_\$</math>, is shown to be equal to the dollar return on euro deposits, <math>\frac {E_t(S_{t + k})} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>.
===Approximation=== Uncovered interest rate parity asserts that an investor with dollar deposits will earn the interest rate available on dollar deposits, while an investor holding euro deposits will earn the interest rate available in the eurozone, but also a potential gain or loss on euros depending on the rate of appreciation or depreciation of the euro against the dollar. Economists have extrapolated a useful approximation of uncovered interest rate parity that follows intuitively from these assumptions. If uncovered interest rate parity holds, such that an investor is indifferent between dollar versus euro deposits, then any excess return on euro deposits must be offset by some expected loss from depreciation of the euro against the dollar. Conversely, some shortfall in return on euro deposits must be offset by some expected gain from appreciation of the euro against the dollar. The following equation represents the uncovered interest rate parity approximation.<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" />
:<math>i_\$ = i_c + \frac {{\Delta}E_t(S_{t + k})} {S_t}</math>
where :<math>{{\Delta}E_t(S_{t + k})}</math> is the change in the expected future spot exchange rate :<math>{{\Delta}E_t(S_{t + k})} / {S_t}</math> is the expected rate of depreciation of the dollar
A more universal way of stating the approximation is "the home interest rate equals the foreign interest rate plus the expected rate of depreciation of the home currency."<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" />
==Covered interest rate parity== [[File:Covered-interest-rate-parity.svg|thumb|right|375px|A visual representation of covered interest rate parity holding in the foreign exchange market, such that the returns from investing domestically are equal to the returns from investing abroad.]] When the no-arbitrage condition is satisfied ''with'' the use of a forward contract to hedge against exposure to exchange rate risk, interest rate parity is said to be ''covered''. Investors will still be indifferent among the available interest rates in two countries because the forward exchange rate sustains equilibrium such that the dollar return on dollar deposits is equal to the dollar return on foreign deposit, thereby eliminating the potential for [[covered interest arbitrage]] profits. Furthermore, covered interest rate parity helps explain the [[forward exchange rate#Relation to covered interest rate parity|determination of the forward exchange rate]]. The following equation represents covered interest rate parity.<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" /><ref name="Waki 2007">{{Cite news | title = No end in sight for yen carry craze | author = Waki, Natsuko | date = 2007-02-21 | publisher = Reuters | url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2007/02/21/us-yen-carry-idUSL218404520070221 | accessdate = 2012-07-09}}</ref>
:<math>(1 + i_\$) = \frac {F_t} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>
where :<math>F_t</math> is the forward exchange rate at time ''t''
The dollar return on dollar deposits, <math>1 + i_\$</math>, is shown to be equal to the dollar return on euro deposits, <math>\frac {F_t} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>.
==Empirical evidence== Covered interest rate parity (CIRP) is found to hold when there is open capital mobility and limited [[capital control]]s, and this finding is confirmed for all currencies freely traded in the present-day. One such example is when the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Germany]] abolished capital controls between 1979 and 1981. [[Maurice Obstfeld]] and Alan Taylor calculated hypothetical profits as implied by the expression of a potential inequality in the CIRP equation (meaning a difference in returns on domestic versus foreign assets) during the 1960s and 1970s, which would have constituted arbitrage opportunities if not for the prevalence of capital controls. However, given financial liberalization and resulting capital mobility, arbitrage temporarily became possible until equilibrium was restored. Since the abolition of capital controls in the United Kingdom and Germany, potential arbitrage profits have been near zero. Factoring in [[transaction cost]]s arising from [[fee]]s and other [[financial regulation|regulations]], arbitrage opportunities are fleeting or nonexistent when such costs exceed deviations from parity.<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" /><ref name="Levi 2005">{{Cite book | title = International Finance, 4th Edition | author = Levi, Maurice D. | year = 2005 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York, NY | isbn = 978-0-415-30900-4}}</ref> While CIRP generally holds, it does not hold with precision due to the presence of transaction costs, [[political risk]]s, [[tax]] implications for interest earnings versus gains from foreign exchange, and differences in the liquidity of domestic versus foreign assets.<ref name="Levi 2005" /><ref name="Dunn & Mutti 2004">{{Cite book | title = International Economics, 6th Edition | author = Dunn, Robert M., Jr. | author2 = Mutti, John H. | year = 2004 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York, NY | isbn = 978-0-415-31154-0}}</ref><ref name="Frenkel & Levich 1981">{{Cite journal | title = Covered interest arbitrage in the 1970's | journal = Economics Letters | volume = 8 | issue = 3 | year = 1981 | author = Frenkel, Jacob A. | author2 = Levich, Richard M. | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/016517658190077X | accessdate = 2011-07-15}}</ref> Researchers found evidence that significant deviations from CIRP during the onset of the [[2007–2012 global financial crisis|global financial crisis]] in 2007 and 2008 were driven by concerns over risk posed by counter parties to banks and financial institutions in Europe and the US in the [[foreign exchange swap]] market. The [[European Central Bank]]'s efforts to provide US dollar liquidity in the foreign exchange swap market, along with similar efforts by the [[Federal Reserve System|Federal Reserve]], had a moderating impact on CIRP deviations between the dollar and the euro. Such a scenario was found to be reminiscent of deviations from CIRP during the 1990s driven by struggling Japanese banks which looked toward foreign exchange swap markets to try and acquire dollars to bolster their [[credit risk|creditworthiness]].<ref name="Baba & Packer 2009">{{Cite journal | title = Interpreting deviations from covered interest parity during the financial market turmoil of 2007-08 | journal = Journal of Banking & Finance | volume = 33 | issue = 11 | year = 2009 | pages = 1953–1962 | author = Baba, Naohiko | author2 = Packer, Frank | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378426609001083 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref>
When both covered and uncovered interest rate parity (UIRP) hold, such a condition sheds light on a noteworthy relationship between the forward and expected future spot exchange rates, as demonstrated below.
:<math>UIRP: (1 + i_\$) = \frac {E_t(S_{t + k})} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>
:<math>CIRP: (1 + i_\$) = \frac {F_t} {S_t} (1 + i_c)</math>
Dividing the equation for UIRP by the equation for CIRP yields the following equation:
:<math>1 = \frac {E_t(S_{t + k})} {F_t}</math>
which can be rewritten as:
:<math>{F_t} = E_t(S_{t + k})</math>
This equation represents the [[forward exchange rate#Unbiasedness hypothesis|unbiasedness hypothesis]], which states that the forward exchange rate is an unbiased predictor of the future spot exchange rate.<ref name="Delcoure et al. 2003">{{Cite journal | title = The Forward Rate Unbiasedness Hypothesis Reexamined: Evidence from a New Test | journal = Global Finance Journal | volume = 14 | issue = 1 | year = 2003 | pages = 83–93 | author = Delcoure, Natalya | author2 = Barkoulas, John | author3 = Baum, Christopher F. | author4 = Chakraborty, Atreya | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1044028303000061 | accessdate = 2011-06-21 | doi=10.1016/S1044-0283(03)00006-1}}</ref><ref name="Ho 2003">{{Cite journal | title = A re-examination of the unbiasedness forward rate hypothesis using dynamic SUR model | journal = The Quarterly Review of Economics and Finance | volume = 43 | issue = 3 | year = 2003 | pages = 542–559 | author = Ho, Tsung-Wu | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1062976902001710 | accessdate = 2011-06-23 | doi=10.1016/S1062-9769(02)00171-0}}</ref> Given strong evidence that CIRP holds, the forward rate unbiasedness hypothesis can serve as a test to determine whether UIRP holds (in order for the forward rate and spot rate to be equal, both CIRP and UIRP conditions must hold). Evidence for the validity and accuracy of the unbiasedness hypothesis, particularly evidence for [[cointegration]] between the forward rate and future spot rate, is mixed as researchers have published numerous papers demonstrating both empirical support and empirical failure of the hypothesis.<ref name="Delcoure et al. 2003" />
UIRP is found to have some empirical support in [[statistical hypothesis testing|tests]] for [[correlation]] between expected rates of [[depreciation (currency)|currency depreciation]] and the [[forward exchange rate#Forward premium or discount|forward premium or discount]].<ref name="Feenstra & Taylor 2008" /> Evidence suggests that whether UIRP holds depends on the currency examined, and deviations from UIRP have been found to be less substantial when examining longer time horizons.<ref name="Bekaert et al. 2007">{{Cite journal | title = Uncovered interest rate parity and the term structure | journal = Journal of International Money and Finance | volume = 26 | issue = 6 | year = 2007 | pages = 1038–1069 | author = Bekaert, Geert | author2 = Wei, Min | author3 = Xing, Yuhang | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261560607000630 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref> Some studies of monetary policy have offered explanations for why UIRP fails empirically. Researchers demonstrated that if a central bank manages interest rate spreads in strong response to the previous period's spreads, that interest rate spreads had negative coefficients in regression tests of UIRP. Another study which setup a model wherein the central bank's monetary policy responds to [[exogenous]] shocks, that the central bank's smoothing of interest rates can explain empirical failures of UIRP.<ref name="Anker 1999">{{Cite journal | title = Uncovered interest parity, monetary policy and time-varying risk premia | journal = Journal of International Money and Finance | volume = 18 | issue = 6 | year = 1999 | pages = 835–851 | author = Anker, Peter | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261560699000364 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref> A study of central bank interventions on the US dollar and [[Deutsche mark]] found only limited evidence of any substantial effect on deviations from UIRP.<ref name="Baillie & Osterberg 2000">{{Cite journal | title = Deviations from daily uncovered interest rate parity and the role of intervention | journal = Journal of International Financial Markets, Institutions and Money | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | year = 2000 | pages = 363–379 | author = Baillie, Richard T. | author2 = Osterberg, William P. | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1042443100000299 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref> UIRP has been found to hold over very small spans of time (covering only a number of hours) with a high frequency of bilateral exchange rate data.<ref name="Chaboud & Wright 2005">{{Cite journal | title = Uncovered interest parity: it works, but not for long | journal = Journal of International Economics | volume = 66 | issue = 2 | year = 2005 | pages = 349–362 | author = Chaboud, Alain P. | author2 = Wright, Jonathan H. | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022199604001175 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref> Tests of UIRP for economies experiencing institutional [[regime change]]s, using monthly exchange rate data for the US dollar versus the Deutsche mark and the [[Spanish peseta]] versus the [[pound sterling|British pound]], have found some evidence that UIRP held when US and German regime changes were volatile, and held between Spain and the United Kingdom particularly after Spain joined the [[European Union]] in 1986 and began liberalizing capital mobility.<ref name="Beyaert et al. 2007">{{Cite journal | title = Uncovered interest parity with switching regimes | journal = Economic Modelling | volume = 24 | issue = 2 | year = 2007 | pages = 189–202 | author = Beyaert, Arielle | author2 = García-Solanes, José | author3 = Pérez-Castejón, Juan J. | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264999306000745 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref>
==Real interest rate parity== When both UIRP (particularly in its approximation form) and purchasing power parity (PPP) hold, the two parity conditions together reveal a relationship among expected real interest rates, wherein changes in expected real interest rates reflect expected changes in the real exchange rate. This condition is known as ''real interest rate parity'' (RIRP) and is related to the [[international Fisher effect]].<ref name="Cuthbertson & Nitzsche 2005">{{Cite book | title = Quantitative Financial Economics: Stocks, Bonds and Foreign Exchange, 2nd Edition | author = Cuthbertson, Keith | author2 = Nitzsche, Dirk | year = 2005 | publisher = John Wiley & Sons | location = Chichester, UK | isbn = 978-0-47-009171-5}}</ref><ref name="Juselius 2006">{{Cite book | title = The Cointegrated VAR Model: Methodology and Applications | author = Juselius, Katarina | year = 2006 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford, UK | isbn = 978-0-19-928566-2}}</ref><ref name="Eun & Resnick 2011">{{Cite book | title = International Financial Management, 6th Edition | author = Eun, Cheol S. | author2 = Resnick, Bruce G. | year = 2011 | publisher = McGraw-Hill/Irwin | location = New York, NY | isbn = 978-0-07-803465-7}}</ref><ref name="Moosa 2003">{{Cite book | title = International Financial Operations: Arbitrage, Hedging, Speculation, Financing and Investment | author = Moosa, Imad A. | year = 2003 | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | location = New York, NY | isbn = 0-333-99859-6}}</ref><ref name="Bordo 2000">{{Cite conference | title = The Globalization of International Financial Markets: What Can History Teach Us? | author = Bordo, Michael D. | author2 = National Bureau of Economic Research | conference = International Financial Markets: The Challenge of Globalization | publisher = Texas A&M University | location = College Station, TX| date = 2000-03-31 | url = http://econweb.rutgers.edu/bordo/global.pdf}}</ref> The following equations demonstrate how to derive the RIRP equation.
:<math>UIRP: {\Delta}E_t(S_{t + k}) = E_t(S_{t + k}) - S_t = i_\$ - i_c</math>
:<math>PPP: {\Delta}E_t(S_{t + k}) = {\Delta}E_t({p^$}_{t + k}) - {\Delta}E_t({p^c}_{t + k})</math> where :<math>p</math> represents inflation
If the above conditions hold, then they can be combined and rearranged as the following: :<math>RIRP: i_$ - {\Delta}E_t({p^$}_{t + k}) = i_c - {\Delta}E_t({p^c}_{t + k})</math>
RIRP rests on several assumptions, including [[Efficient-market hypothesis|efficient markets]], no country risk premia, and zero change in the expected real exchange rate. The parity condition suggests that real interest rates will equalize between countries and that capital mobility will result in capital flows that eliminate opportunities for arbitrage. There exists strong evidence that RIRP holds tightly among emerging markets in Asia and also Japan. The half-life period of deviations from RIRP have been examined by researchers and found to be roughly six or seven months, but between two and three months for certain countries. Such variation in the half-lives of deviations may be reflective of differences in the degree of financial integration among the country groups analyzed.<ref name="Baharumshah et al. 2005">{{Cite journal | title = A panel study on real interest rate parity in East Asian countries: Pre- and post-liberalization era | journal = Global Finance Journal | volume = 16 | issue = 1 | year = 2005 | pages = 69–85 | author = Baharumshah, Ahmad Zubaidi | author2 = Haw, Chan Tze | author3 = Fountas, Stilianos | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1044028305000177 | accessdate = 2011-07-21}}</ref> RIRP does not hold over short time horizons, but empirical evidence has demonstrated that it generally holds well across long time horizons of five to ten years.<ref name="Chinn 2007">{{Cite encyclopedia | title = Interest Parity Conditions | author = Chinn, Menzie D. | encyclopedia = Princeton Encyclopedia of the World Economy | editor = Reinert, Kenneth A. | editor2 = Rajan, Ramkishen S. | editor3 = Glass, Amy Jocelyn | editor4 = Davis, Lewis S. | year = 2007 | publisher = Princeton University Press | location = Princeton, NJ | isbn = 978-0-69-112812-2}}</ref>
